x10.constraint.xnative
Class XPromise

java.lang.Object
  x10.constraint.xnative.XPromise
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
public class XPromise
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable

All nodes that occur in the graph maintained by a constraint must implement Promise. Thus a Promise is a pointer into the state of some specific constraint.

A promise contains fields:

  1. XPromise value -- if non-null, points to a promise this one has been equated with.
  2. Collection disequals -- contains set of other nodes this has been disequated with
  3. XTerm var -- externally visible term labeling this promise
  4. Map fields -- hashmap of fields of this promise (if any).
It maintains the invariant > value != null implies disequals==null && fields == null. That is, if value !=null (in this case we say the promise ie bound), all further information about this node in the graph is found by going to to value, except for the XTerm labeling this node (var). See term().

If a.value==b we sometimes say that b has an incoming "eq" link, and a has an outgoing "eq" link.

Constraint graphs may contain sequences of such bindings. These can be shortened without any semantic consequence.

Constraint graphs are always acyclic.

Note: This class is not public only so that extensions of this constraint system may use it. This interface is not intended to be used by customers of the constraint system.

Author:
vj
See Also:

                XPromise value,

Create a new promise with the given fields, the given label (var) and pointing to value. Either value==null || fields==null. var may also be null.

Parameters:
var - -- the term labeling the promise
value - -- the XTerm that this promise points to
fields - -- the fields of the promise.
Method Detail

value

public XPromise value()
A promise to which this promise is bound.

term

public XNativeTerm term()
Return the term that labels this promise. This term is intended to be the canonical XTerm labeling this promise, following the direct path from the root node. Note: this promise may be forwarded to another; yet the term returned is this's term, not the term corresponding to the target promise.

Returns:
null if this promise is an internal promise.

fields

public java.util.Map<java.lang.Object,XPromise> fields()
Map from field names f to promises term().f

setTerm

public void setTerm(XNativeTerm term)
Set the term corresponding to this promise. The term may be null, such a promise is called a silent promise. Silent promises are not dumped (that is, they do not correspond to constraints on externally visible terms). They correspond to internal nodes that are used just for implementation efficiency.

Parameters:
term -

setTerm

public void setTerm(XNativeTerm term,
                    java.util.Set<XPromise> visited)

forwarded

public boolean forwarded()
Has this promise been forwarded?

Returns:
true if it has been forwarded (its value !=null)

intern

public XPromise intern(XNativeVar[] vars,
                       int index)
                throws XFailure
this must be the promise corresponding to the index'th element in the list vars. Return the node in the graph of constraint c obtained by following the path specified by vars[index],.., vars[vars.length-1] from this node.

Create new nodes if necessary so that this path is defined in the graph of c.

Parameters:
vars - vars must be a sequence XVar, XField, ... XField, satisfying the property that the receiver of each element (other than the first) is the preceding element.
index -
c -
Returns:
the node at the end of the path. This must not be a forwarded node.
Throws:
XFailure

intern

public XPromise intern(XNativeVar[] vars,
                       int index,
                       XPromise last)
vars is as above. If last is not null, then do not create a new promise for vars[index-1], instead use last.

Returns:
Throws:
XFailure

addIn

public void addIn(java.lang.Object s,
                  XPromise orphan,
                  XNativeConstraint parent)
           throws XFailure
An eq link entering this has just been established. Now the children of the source of the link have to be transferred to this. If this does not have an s-child, then install the child as its s-child. If it does, then recursively bind the s-child to this's s child.

Parameters:
s - -- the name of the field
child - -- the s child of the source of the eq link.
Throws:
XFailure

bind

public boolean bind(XPromise target,
                    XNativeConstraint parent)
             throws XFailure
Bind this promise to the given target. All the children of this, if any, have to be added into the target. target should satisfy the condition that it is not forwarded. Return true if the execution of this operation caused a change to the constraint graph; false otherwise.

Parameters:
target -
Throws:
XFailure

disBind

public boolean disBind(XPromise target)
                throws XFailure
Bind this promise to the given target using a NOT link. target should satisfy the condition that it is not forwarded. Note that the following is consistent: X !=Y, X.f=Y.f.

Parameters:
target - The term to be notBound to.
Returns:
true if the execution of this operation caused a change in the constraint graph; false otherwise.
Throws:
XFailure - in case this is already bound to target.

canReach

public boolean canReach(XPromise p)
Is there a path from here to p? Can this promise reach p in the directed graph representing the constraints?

visit

public boolean visit(XNativeVar path,
                     XGraphVisitor xg,
                     XNativeConstraint parent)
Let t1 be path (if path is not null), else the term labeling this promise. If this promise has an outgoing edge to t2, and either dumpEQV is true or ! t1.hasEQV(), then output t1==t2 to result, unless hideFake is true and one of t1 or t2 is a fake field. If this promise has fields, then recursively continue dumping with the children, passing them a path t1.f (for field f) if t1 is an instance of XVar, otherwise passing a path null (in this case t1 is an atom and the children are its subterms). (This takes care of multiple paths entering the promise.)

Parameters:
result -
oldSelf -
